claim: All cats are mammals. Tigers belong to the cat family. Therefore, tigers are mammals

supporting.text: All cats are members of the biological family Felidae, which is classified under the class Mammalia, meaning all cats are mammals by definition.

attacks.text: All cats are members of the biological family Felidae, which is classified under the class Mammalia, meaning all cats are mammals by definition.
Some members of the Felidae family, such as extinct species, may not have been mammals due to differing evolutionary traits.
Fossil records confirm that all known extinct Felidae species exhibit mammalian characteristics like lactation and fur.
Classification systems can be revised, and future discoveries might reclassify some Felidae species as non-mammalian.
Current taxonomic consensus, backed by genetic and morphological evidence, strongly supports Felidae as exclusively mammalian.

supporting.text: Tigers (Panthera tigris) are scientifically classified under the Felidae family, which confirms their membership in the cat family.

attacks.text: Tigers (Panthera tigris) are scientifically classified under the Felidae family, which confirms their membership in the cat family.
Some subspecies of tigers may have genetic anomalies that challenge their strict classification under Felidae.
Genetic studies overwhelmingly confirm that all tiger subspecies fit within the Felidae family without exception.
The term 'cat family' is colloquial and lacks precise scientific boundaries, which could exclude certain members like tigers.
Taxonomic conventions explicitly define Felidae to include all species commonly referred to as 'cats,' including tigers.
Hybridization between tigers and other species could blur their classification within the cat family.
Hybridization does not alter the fundamental taxonomic classification of tigers as members of the Felidae family.

supporting.text: Mammals are defined by characteristics such as having mammary glands, hair, and three middle ear bones, all of which tigers possess.

attacks.text: Mammals are defined by characteristics such as having mammary glands, hair, and three middle ear bones, all of which tigers possess.
Some tigers may exhibit genetic mutations that result in the absence of one or more mammalian characteristics, such as hair or mammary glands.
Genetic mutations affecting mammalian traits are extremely rare and do not change the species' classification as mammals.
The fossil record shows transitional species between reptiles and mammals, suggesting that mammalian traits are not strictly binary.
Transitional species are irrelevant to the classification of modern tigers, which clearly exhibit all mammalian traits.

supporting.text: The taxonomic classification system places both domestic cats and tigers under the same order (Carnivora) and family (Felidae), reinforcing their shared mammalian traits.

attacks.text: The taxonomic classification system places both domestic cats and tigers under the same order (Carnivora) and family (Felidae), reinforcing their shared mammalian traits.
Taxonomic classifications are based on morphological and genetic similarities, which do not necessarily imply identical biological traits like mammalian characteristics.
Some species within the same family can exhibit exceptions to general traits, such as non-mammalian reproductive methods in rare cases.
Genetic studies confirm that all members of Felidae share common mammalian ancestry, making exceptions highly unlikely.
No known species in the Felidae family deviate from mammalian traits, making such exceptions purely hypothetical.
Even with shared ancestry, convergent evolution or genetic mutations could theoretically produce non-mammalian traits in Felidae.
